content: Decision tree for preventive health services based on age and sex

children.content: Defined as examination of asymptomatic individuals to detect those with a given disease or risk factor
Based on strength of supporting evidence and size of net benefit
Strongly recommend, good evidence that service improves outcomes, benefits substantially outweigh harms
Recommend, at least fair evidence that service improves outcomes, benefits outweigh harms
No recommendation for or against, fair evidence that service can improve outcomes, benefits/harms balance too close
Recommend against, fair evidence that service is ineffective or harm outweighs benefits
Insufficient evidence to recommend for or against, evidence lacking/poor quality/conflicting, benefits/harms balance undetermined
Preventive services based on age group and sex
The USPSTF strongly recommends screening women for cervical cancer if they have a cervix and have been sexually active (Grade A)
A revaccination with MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) is also recommended for those students entering a postsecondary educational institution
The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen all sexually active women ≤25 years for chlamydial infection (Grade A) and gonorrheal infection (Grade B).
A revaccination with MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) is also recommended for those students entering a postsecondary educational institution
The USPSTF strongly recommends screening women for cervical cancer if they have a cervix and have been sexually active (Grade A).

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).
The USPSTF recommends screening mammography, with or without clinical breast examination, every 1–2 years for women aged ≥40 (Grade B).
The USPSTF strongly recommends screening women for cervical cancer if they have a cervix and have been sexually active (Grade A).

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).
The USPSTF recommends screening mammography, with or without clinical breast examination, every 1–2 years for women aged ≥40 (Grade B).
The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians screen men and women ≥50 years for colorectal cancer (Grade A)
The USPSTF strongly recommends screening women for cervical cancer if they have a cervix and have been sexually active (Grade A).
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends annual influenza vaccine for all persons ≥50 years and persons in selected high-risk groups.

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).
The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians screen men and women ≥50 years for colorectal cancer (Grade A)
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends annual influenza vaccine for all persons ≥50 years and persons in selected high-risk groups.

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).

The USPSTF concludes that the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against routine screening for prostate cancer using prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing or digital rectal examination (DRE) (Grade I).
The USPSTF recommends screening mammography, with or without clinical breast examination, every 1–2 years for women aged ≥40 (Grade B).
The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians screen men and women ≥50 years for colorectal cancer (Grade A)
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends annual influenza vaccine for all persons ≥50 years and persons in selected high-risk groups.

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).

The USPSTF recommends that women ≥65 years be screened routinely for osteoporosis and that routine screening begin at age 60 years in women who are at increased risk for osteoporotic fractures (Grade B).
Pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for all immunocompetent individuals who are ≥65 years or otherwise at increased risk for pneumococcal disease.
The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians screen men and women ≥50 years for colorectal cancer (Grade A)
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends annual influenza vaccine for all persons ≥50 years and persons in selected high-risk groups.

The USPSTF strongly recommends that clinicians routinely screen men ≥35 years and women ≥45 years for lipid disorders and treat abnormal lipids in people who are at increased risk for coronary heart disease (Grade A).

The USPSTF concludes that the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against routine screening for prostate cancer using prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing or digital rectal examination (DRE) (Grade I).
Pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for all immunocompetent individuals who are ≥65 years or otherwise at increased risk for pneumococcal disease.
